cards.title: Command Line
cards.content: Why do hackers use black screens with green text? It’s not just to look cool. It’s the Command Line (Terminal). Windows/Mac use a GUI (Graphical User Interface)—icons and mouse clicks. It’s user-friendly but slow. The Command Line talks directly to the OS. Typing `mv *.jpg /folder` moves 1,000 photos instantly. Dragging them with a mouse takes forever. The Command Line is less intuitive, but infinitely more powerful. It’s the difference between driving an automatic and driving a manual racecar.
cards.keyTakeaway: The Command Line is a text-based way to control computers faster than a mouse.

quiz.question: What is the advantage of the Command Line Interface (CLI)?
choices: B: It allows for faster, more powerful control
quiz.explanation: It bypasses the graphical layer for direct, scriptable interaction with the system.

cards.title: Metadata
cards.content: You take a photo and send it to a friend. You think you just sent an image. You actually sent a packet of Metadata (EXIF data). Hidden inside the file is: The camera model, the exact time, the shutter speed, and... the GPS coordinates of where you stood. Strangers can download your photo and see exactly where you live. Social media sites (Instagram/FB) usually strip this data out, but emailing or texting files often keeps it. Data isn't just the content; it's the context.
cards.keyTakeaway: Metadata is hidden info (like GPS location) attached to digital files.

quiz.question: What kind of information can be found in photo Metadata?
choices: B: GPS location and time taken
quiz.explanation: EXIF data records technical details and often location coordinates.

cards.title: Botnets
cards.content: A Botnet is a zombie army of computers. Hackers infect thousands of devices with malware. These computers work normally for their owners, but silently, they are waiting for a command. When the hacker says 'Attack,' all 10,000 computers wake up and spam a target or mine crypto. You could be part of a botnet right now and not know it. This is why slow computers aren't just annoying; they are suspicious. Your laptop might be living a double life.
cards.keyTakeaway: Hackers control armies of infected computers called Botnets.

quiz.question: What is a Botnet?
choices: B: A network of infected computers controlled by a hacker
quiz.explanation: It allows a single attacker to wield the power of thousands of devices.

cards.title: Two-Factor Authentication
cards.content: Passwords are dead. They get stolen constantly. The fix is 2FA (Two-Factor Authentication). It requires two things: 1. Something you know (Password). 2. Something you have (Phone/Security Key). Even if a hacker steals your password, they can't log in because they don't have your phone to get the 6-digit code. It blocks 99.9% of automated attacks. If you don't have 2FA on your email and bank, you are leaving your front door unlocked in a bad neighborhood.
cards.keyTakeaway: 2FA adds a second lock that requires your physical device to open.

quiz.question: What are the two factors in 2FA?
choices: B: Something you know (password) + Something you have (device)
quiz.explanation: It combines knowledge with physical possession for security.

cards.title: Silicon Valley
cards.content: Why is it called 'Silicon' Valley? Because silicon is the main ingredient in semiconductors (computer chips). Silicon is a semiconductor—it can conduct electricity sometimes, and block it other times. This switching (On/Off) is the binary code (1/0) of all computing. The area south of San Francisco became the hub for chip manufacturing in the 70s (Intel, AMD). Now it makes software, but the name honors the chemical element that makes the digital age possible. It’s basically 'Sand Valley.'
cards.keyTakeaway: Silicon is the material used to make computer chips.

quiz.question: Why is Silicon used in computers?
choices: A: It is a semiconductor (controls electricity)
quiz.explanation: Its ability to switch between conducting and insulating is the basis of binary logic.

cards.title: Fiber Optics
cards.content: The internet travels at the speed of light. Literally. Fiber Optic cables are thin strands of glass (thinner than hair). We shoot pulses of laser light down them. The light bounces off the internal walls of the glass (total internal reflection) and travels thousands of miles without losing brightness. 99% of international internet traffic travels through undersea fiber cables on the ocean floor. If sharks bite them (which they do), the internet slows down. We live in a world connected by glass threads.
cards.keyTakeaway: Fiber optics transmit data as light pulses through glass strands.

quiz.question: What travels inside a fiber optic cable?
quiz.explanation: Data is converted into pulses of light (lasers) that travel through the glass core.

cards.title: The Save Icon
cards.content: Ask a teenager what the 'Save' icon is. They will say 'It's a square.' They don't know it's a Floppy Disk. Floppy disks were storage devices in the 80s/90s that held 1.44 MB (less than one song). We stopped using them 20 years ago, but the symbol stayed. It is a 'Skeuomorph'—a design element that mimics a real-world object that is no longer necessary. Like the 'shutter sound' on your digital camera (which has no shutter). Technology moves forward, but icons look backward.
cards.keyTakeaway: The Save icon is a picture of a Floppy Disk, an obsolete storage format.

quiz.question: What real-world object is the Save icon based on?
quiz.explanation: It persists as a symbol despite the physical object being obsolete.

cards.title: GIGO
cards.content: Garbage In, Garbage Out. This is the golden rule of computing. Computers aren't magic; they are logic machines. If you feed them bad data (Garbage In), they will give you bad results (Garbage Out), no matter how powerful the computer is. If you train an AI on racist internet comments, it will become a racist AI. If you put wrong numbers in a spreadsheet, the graph will be wrong. Errors are rarely the computer's fault; they are usually the user's fault.
cards.keyTakeaway: Computers produce bad results if given bad data.

quiz.question: What does GIGO stand for?
quiz.explanation: It emphasizes that the quality of output is determined by the quality of the input.

cards.title: Easter Eggs
cards.content: Programmers get bored. So they hide secrets in software. These are 'Easter Eggs.' The first one was in the Atari game 'Adventure' (1979), where the creator hid his name in a secret room because the company wouldn't credit him. Now they are everywhere. If you Google 'Do a barrel roll,' the screen spins. If you type 'askew,' it tilts. Tesla cars can dance. It adds humanity to the cold code. It’s a secret handshake between the creator and the user.
cards.keyTakeaway: Easter Eggs are hidden secrets or jokes inside software.

quiz.question: Why do programmers include Easter Eggs?
choices: B: For fun and to leave a signature
quiz.explanation: They are hidden features intended to amuse users or credit the creators.

cards.title: The First Computer Bug
cards.content: Why do we call computer errors 'bugs'? Because the first one was literal. In 1947, computer pioneer Grace Hopper was working on the Mark II computer at Harvard. It malfunctioned. When they opened the massive machine, they found a moth stuck in a relay switch. It had been 'electrocuted' and stopped the circuit. They taped the dead moth into the logbook with the note: 'First actual case of bug being found.' We've been 'debugging' code ever since, though usually, the pests are logic errors, not insects.
cards.keyTakeaway: The first computer bug was a real moth trapped in a machine.

quiz.question: Who found the first literal computer bug?
quiz.explanation: Grace Hopper and her team found a moth inside the Mark II computer in 1947.

cards.title: Deep Web vs Dark Web
cards.content: People confuse the 'Deep Web' with the 'Dark Web.' They are different. The Deep Web is just anything you need a password to see (your email, banking, private Netflix account). It is 90% of the internet. It’s boring and safe. The Dark Web is a small slice of the Deep Web that is intentionally hidden and requires special software (Tor) to access. Deep Web = Private (like your house). Dark Web = Hidden (like a secret bunker). You use the Deep Web every day.
cards.keyTakeaway: The Deep Web is just private pages (email); the Dark Web is hidden.

quiz.question: Is your email inbox part of the Deep Web or Dark Web?
quiz.explanation: It is not indexed by search engines but is accessible with a password, making it Deep Web.
